"SECTION 1. FINDINGS." "Mercy Ships, founded in 1978, has provided services in over 70 countries valued at $1.3 billion, treating 2.56 million beneficiaries. They operate the Africa Mercy, the world's largest private hospital ship, with 5 operating rooms and space for 82 patients. The volunteer crew includes surgeons, nurses, doctors, and other professionals, performing over 82,000 life-changing operations." Mercy Ships has provided various medical services including dental procedures, training local professionals in different specialties, teaching basic health care to local people, and completing infrastructure projects to improve healthcare delivery systems. Mercy Ships has over 1,600 volunteers annually, with 900 serving in Africa. The Africa Mercy has had over 4,900 crew members from 74 countries since 2007. They have completed over 589 port visits in 73 nations, including both developing and developed countries. Mercy Ships has had four hospital ships serving in various countries including Canada, China, Congo Brazzaville, Colombia, Cuba, and many others. Mercy Ships has operated several hospital ships in different regions, including Africa, Guatemala, the Caribbean, Central and South America. The ships varied in size and crew capacity, with missions focused on providing medical relief and services to those in need. Mercy Ships operated hospital ships in various regions, including Africa, Guatemala, the Caribbean, Central and South America. The largest ship, the Africa Mercy, served in the South Pacific before being sold in 2001. A new hospital ship is being built to serve Africa for the next 50 years, with a focus on healthcare training and safe surgery. Mercy Ships has hosted Presidents and heads of state onboard their ships. Mercy Ships has received endorsements from various world leaders and heads of state for providing free healthcare on their hospital ships. Don Stephens, President and Founder of Mercy Ships, will be awarded a Congressional Gold Medal. The medal will be designed and struck by the Secretary of the Treasury. Duplicates in bronze may be sold under specific regulations. The medals struck under this Act are national medals and considered numismatic items under title 31, United States Code.
